text.p: The following are leading domestic stories in Portuguese newspapers.

- Jorge Coelho, Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, said a referendum on regionalisation would take place in the first half of 1998. He was responding to remarks by opposition Social Democrat leader Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, who had said the referendum would not be held before 1999.

- The U.N.'s representative in Angola, Alioune Blondin Beye, and the U.N. Security Council said UNITA members of the parliament would take their seats on April 9, and that the national unity government will take office on April 11.
- Portugal Telecom decided not to identify its strategic partner at its general shareholders' meeting yesterday, despite talk of an agreement with the Angolo-American group Concert.
- The government runs the risk of having to pay 70 billion escudos to rescue ailing cereals firm EPAC.
- Economy Minister Augusto Mateus visits the United States from today to encourage carbuilders to invest in Portugal.
- The German group BASF creates a new textiles subsidiary in Portugal, BASF-Curtumes e Texteis.

- Portugal's insurance sector will maintain a strong annual growth rate of around 15 percent for the foreseeable future, after having grown at an annual rate of some 22 percent over the last five years, according to a report by the Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS).
